<headline>
Nepal Road Closure & Infrastructure Issues Megathread
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="shikibu" datetime="2015-06-01T14:21:00">
This is a dedicated thread for sharing current information about road closures and other infrastructural issues that may affect travelers.
Please stay on topic and keep all posts about these topics within this thread, to make the Nepal branch easier to use.
</post>
<post id="p2" author="doooooosra" datetime="2015-06-01T15:52:00">
Some thoughts to start with (no links for now):
Roads:
To Kodari and the Tibetan border, of interest to those intending to overland to/from Tibet. - it was blacked near to tatopani, not sure if traffic is getting to Kodari.
To Langtang - blocked north od Dhunche preventing access to Syabrubesi for treks to Langyang valley and the Tamang Heritage Trail (but see below).

To Jomsom - a landslide blocked the Kali gandaki causing a lake. The river is flowing over the blockage so the lake is not getting any larger but the water covers the road. The army are attempting to blast away the blockage but no news of total success yet.

All other major roads of interest to travellers seem to be open. The Prithvi Highway between KTM and Pokhara is open and clear with buses operating normally. The roads between Pokhara, Lumbini and Chitwan are open as the ones from these places to KTM. The East-West highway in the teraibetween Bardia in the west to Kakarbhitta in the east was not affected.
Treks:
Langtang - severe damage, closed but the authorties..
Tamang Heritage Trail - not possible/very difficult to access, damage likely to be very bad, I assume it is officialy closed too.
Gosainkund 0 I understnd the lodges are damaged and closed.
Helambu - little specific information (other than Chisapani is undamaged) but this trek is in Sindhupulchok district which was said to be the worst hit,
Manaslu - lots of damage to buidlings, landslides blocking significant parts of the trail on the east side, not possible to cross the pass.

Annapurna Circuit - litte damage to buildings, two significant landslides. The first in the Marsyangdi Valley (east side) near Lower Pisang which caused a lake. I understand the dnager of a sudden outflow has padded and higher trails can be taken. The second is north of Beni in the Kali Gandaki valley - see above. Trekkers can avoid this by flying out of Jomsom or turning east at Tatopani to Ghorepani and Poon Hill then to Nay pul for the road to Ghandruk.

Everest Base Camp and other treks in the area - despite significant damage to lodges the main trails to EBC are open to trekkers. Early reports of destroyed villages proved not to be the case and there are reports from trekkers to confirm the route is possible after both major quakes. Gokyo Valley might be difficult with all the lodges in Macchermo and Dole closed due t damage this woul dmake safe acclimatisation very difficult without tents. I do not know about the east side which has/had a couple of lodges. The 3 High passes routes - I have seen little information about Kongma La, Cho La and renjo La trails or the lodges either side of Cho La but lodges in the Thame Valley have suffered - Lungden is closed and Thame itself has a lot of damage. Rolwaling has suffered a lot of damage.
Cities and sights:

KTM, the valley and the valley rim are the only places of major interest to travellers that have been significantly affected. In Pokhara, Chitwan, Lumbini, Bardia and Janakpur the situation is normal. Gorkha is probably badly damaged given its location but I have not seen much information.

The World Heritage sights - the 3 Durbar Suares are heavily damaged and currently closed but reported to opne - though not re-built - by mid-June. Boudhanath has a few cracks but is open. Pashupatinath has some damage but is open. Changu Narayan is damaged but the main temple is intact, don't know if it is open. Swayambunath has lots of damage and is closed.
Information about other sights is thin on the ground. I don;t know how Sanhku and Vajra Yogini have fared nor Ivhangu narayan, Balaju, Buddha Park, Shesh Narayan and Gokarneswor as examples.

Towns and villages -Bungamati and Khokana, Nuwakot have suffered a lot of damage but Nagarkot and Dhulikhel were not damaged too badly and lots of hotels are OK and open, Panauti seems OK, don't know about Kirtipur, Godawari, and Balthali.
Please don't make any plans based on this information because it is a general overview and people will post more up to date info with links but it is a starting point.
</post>
<post id="p3" author="anpijola" datetime="2015-06-01T16:39:00">

The following report gives a first hand info regarding trails and damages between Lukla to Thame. The author traveled between 18-22 May. Damage in Thame is particularly extensive. A stretch of trail between Phakding and Monjo is a bit dangerous. <a href="http://bit.ly/1JjtGiD" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://bit.ly/1JjtGiD</a>
</post>
<post id="p4" author="doooooosra" datetime="2015-06-01T16:56:00">
This blog reports on an EBC trek which included the second quake:
<a href="http://bonatravels.com/category/nepal/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://bonatravels.com/category/nepal/</a>
</post>
<post id="p5" author="mfinglet" datetime="2015-06-02T01:04:00">
I talked with a friend in Seduwa yesterday - he was one of the unlucky ones who's house was affected.
He reported no major damage in Num (slight damage to one house)
69 houses and the govt school were damaged/destroyed in Seduwa but it sounds like they are prepared for monsoon.
The teahouse that was reported destroyed in Yangle Kharka has been repaired.
In general it sounds like Makalu is a good option and open for business (after the monsoon..)
Cheers,
Michael
</post>
<post id="p6" author="heatherf" datetime="2015-06-03T05:36:00">

I've been out to Balthali twice since the earthquakes. Most houses in the area damaged and many unlivable. Balthali Village Resort has major damage to one building but the dining area and some rooms are OK and they are still accepting guests whilst also repairing the damage. The new resort on the next hilltop, which had been open only a month, has been quite badly damaged. As said earlier, Panauti is fine as is Khopasi. Interestingly Panauti also survived the 1934 earthquake.
</post>
<post id="p7" author="STN" datetime="2015-06-03T09:02:00">

Araniko highway (Ktm-Tibet) is closed at the sindupalchok district. Similarly, the Pokhara-Jomsom road have been blocked by landslide. Ktm-Pokhara (Prithivi Highway) is fully in operation.Similarly Mahendra highway (east-west highway) is also in operation. There was a blockage on the road due to landslide on the road from Kathmandu to syafrubesi(the gateway to Langtang valley)at Dhunche. But the blockage have been removed so it also have come into operation. The road that connects to the Annapurrna region is very less affected.
</post>
<post id="p8" author="David380" datetime="2015-06-03T10:29:00">

This article give a more accurate picture of how things are. I'm in Boudha now and to be honest you would be hard pressed to know there had been 2 major quakes in the last month. Some people are still sleeping outside and many buildings have sustained damage but very few have collapsed and most are repairable. All services are available and life here is more or less normal. Ditto for the rest of Kathmandu - there's pockets of serious damage but it's not like the city has been destroyed.

<a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/collegeofjournalism/entries/ae5fd09c-c333-48b5-9b35-06238d7f9e71" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/collegeofjournalism/entries/ae5fd09c-c333-48b5-9b35-06238d7f9e71</a>
</post>
